questions.text: An 8-month-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents for gradually increasing loss of neck control and inability to roll over for the past 2 months. During this time, he has had multiple episodes of unresponsiveness with a blank stare and fluttering of the eyelids. His parents state that he sometimes does not turn when called but gets startled by loud noises. He does not maintain eye contact. He was able to roll over from front to back at 5 months of age and has not yet begun to sit or crawl. His parents are of Ashkenazi Jewish descent. Neurological examination shows generalized hypotonia. Deep tendon reflexes are 3+ bilaterally. Plantar reflex shows extensor response bilaterally. Fundoscopy shows bright red macular spots bilaterally. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Sphingomyelinase deficiency is the cause of Niemann-Pick disease, a sphingolipidosis that leads to neurodegeneration at a young age. It is more prevalent in individuals with Ashkenazi Jewish heritage. Although patients with this disease also present with cherry-red spots on the macula, developmental delay, and regression; the absence of hepatosplenomegaly makes this diagnosis unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

Arylsulfatase A deficiency causes metachromatic leukodystrophy, a sphingolipidosis that can also lead to developmental delay and regression, and hypotonia starting at 6 months of age. However, metachromatic leukodystrophy is not associated with bright red spots on the macula, but rather optic nerve atrophy, ataxia, and peripheral neuropathy.

C) INCORRECT:

Gaucher disease is the most common of the sphingolipidoses and results from a deficiency of β-glucocerebrosidase. It is more prevalent in individuals with Ashkenazi Jewish heritage. Some forms of Gaucher disease can cause seizures, and developmental delay can be seen in more severe cases. However, hepatosplenomegaly, bone abnormalities (pain and osteopenia), and pancytopenia are much more common findings. Also, bright red spots on the macula are inconsistent with Gaucher disease.

D) INCORRECT:

Alpha-galactosidase A deficiency causes Fabry disease, which characteristically leads to severe distal limb pain (due to peripheral neuropathy) and angiokeratomas beginning around the age of 10–17 years. Renal failure and cardiovascular disease occur in most patients between the ages of 30– 40 years. The diagnosis of Fabry disease would not explain this patient's developmental delay that started at 6 months of age, nor would it cause bright red spots on the macula, hypotonia, and absence seizures.

E) INCORRECT:

A deficiency in lysosomal galactocerebrosidase results in Krabbe disease, a sphingolipidosis which can cause developmental delay or regression, similar to the motor symptoms seen in this case. However, patients with Krabbe disease tend to have hypertonia, not hypotonia, and do not have bright red spots on the macula. Instead, visual impairment secondary to optic nerve atrophy and peripheral neuropathy occur.

F) CORRECT:

Beta-hexosaminidase A deficiency is the cause of Tay-Sachs disease, a rare neurological disease that causes intracellular accumulation of GM2 gangliosides in neural cells, leading to progressive neurological degeneration beginning around the age of 6 months and cherry-red spots on fundoscopy. Individuals of Ashkenazi Jewish descent are more prone to develop the disease and carrier testing is therefore commonly performed in pregnant patients of this group or patients who wish to conceive. There is no cure and treatment is largely supportive. Usually, patients die of respiratory infections before 5 years of age. See “Overview of lysosomal storage diseases” table.

The extensor response to the plantar reflex seen in this infant is physiologic and should only be interpreted as a sign of neurologic damage if it persists beyond 24 months of age or is only seen unilaterally.
Image Description:

Fundus photography of the left eye of a child with Tay-Sachs disease

The fovea centralis is visible as a deep red spot (cherry-red spot; blue overlay). Surrounding the fovea, the retina appears paler than normal because of accumulation of gangliosides within the retinal cells.

Differential diagnosis of a cherry-red spot in children include Niemann-Pick disease, in which this appearance is caused by the accumulation of sphingomyelin within the retinal cells. In adults the diagnosis is most likely central retinal artery occlusion.
questions.hint: This infant presents with developmental delay, regression of achieved milestones (inability to roll over despite reaching this milestone three months prior), absence seizures (episodes of unresponsiveness with a blank stare), decreased eye contact, hypotonia, exaggerated startle response as a result of hyperacusis, hearing loss (unresponsive when called), hyperreflexia, and bilateral bright red (“cherry-red”) spots on fundoscopy, all of which are characteristic features of Tay-Sachs disease.

questions.text: An 18-month-old boy is brought to the physician because of a 2-day history of cough, fever, and lethargy. He has been admitted to the hospital twice during the past year for pneumonia. He can stand without support but has not started to walk. He speaks in bisyllables. He is at the 3rd percentile for height and 4th percentile for weight. Examination shows diffuse crackles over bilateral lung fields. Abdominal examination shows hepatosplenomegaly. Fundoscopy shows bright red macular spots. Despite being given appropriate antibiotic therapy, the patient dies. A photomicrograph of a section of the spleen obtained during autopsy is shown. Accumulation of which of the following substances is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Accumulation of limit dextrin is characteristic of Cori disease (type III glycogen storage disease). Although splenomegaly is a clinical feature of Cori disease, cherry-red macular spots and recurrent pneumonia would not be expected.

B) CORRECT:

This patient's clinical features (hepatosplenomegaly, cherry-red macular spots, and psychomotor retardation) and biopsy findings, which show foam cells, are consistent with Niemann-Pick disease. This condition is caused by accumulation of sphingomyelin primarily in lysosomes of the reticuloendothelial system and CNS. Patients with Niemann-Pick disease usually develop normally until 1 year of age, when regression of mental and motor development starts to occur. Additional clinical features such as interstitial lung disease can develop in the type A variant, which manifests with recurrent pneumonia that progresses to respiratory failure and death.

C) INCORRECT:

Accumulation of phenylalanine is characteristic of phenylketonuria (PKU). Although motor regression and developmental delay are clinical features of PKU, cherry-red macular spots and hepatosplenomegaly would not be expected. Furthermore, PKU is most commonly diagnosed in the neonatal period because phenylalanine levels are measured as part of newborn screening for metabolic disorders.

D) INCORRECT:

Accumulation of galactitol is characteristic of galactosemia. Although involvement of the eyes (e.g., cataracts), hepatomegaly, and cognitive impairment are seen in galactosemia, cherry-red macular spots and recurrent pneumonia would not be expected.

E) INCORRECT:

Accumulation of ceramide trihexoside is characteristic of Fabry disease. Fabry disease is the only X-linked recessive sphingolipidosis (meaning it is more likely to occur in males) and typically includes involvement of the eyes (e.g., cataracts, corneal clouding). However, cherry-red macular spots, hepatosplenomegaly, and recurrent pneumonia would not be expected. Furthermore, clinical features of Fabry disease usually only start to develop during late childhood or early adolescence.

F) INCORRECT:

Accumulation of cerebroside sulfate is characteristic of metachromatic leukodystrophy. Although involvement of the eyes (e.g., optic nerve atrophy, blindness), motor regression, and developmental delay would be seen in the condition, cherry-red macular spot, hepatosplenomegaly, and recurrent pneumonia would not be expected.

G) INCORRECT:

Accumulation of GM2 ganglioside is characteristic of Tay-Sachs disease. Although developmental delay, cherry-red macular spots, and death in early childhood are features of Tay-Sachs disease, hepatosplenomegaly and recurrent pneumonia would not be expected. Moreover, histologic findings would show lysosomes with an onion skin appearance (swollen lysosomes with membranes that appear whorled) as opposed to this patient's foam cells.

H) INCORRECT:

Accumulation of glucocerebroside is characteristic of Gaucher disease. Although hepatosplenomegaly is a common feature of Gaucher disease, cherry-red macular spots and recurrent pneumonia would not be expected. Furthermore, histologic findings on microscopic examination would show Gaucher cells (lipid-rich macrophages with an enlarged, crinkled paper-like cytoplasm), which are not present in this patient's biopsy specimen.
questions.hint: Electron microscopy of this patient's spleen specimen would most likely also show zebra bodies.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy with recurrent ear infections is brought to the pediatrician for a follow-up examination. He can walk with support and his vocabulary consists of approximately 50 words. His maternal uncle died in childhood from an unknown disease. Physical examination shows coarse facial features with an enlarged tongue. The abdomen is distended and both the liver and spleen tip are palpable. Laboratory studies show elevated total urinary glycosaminoglycan levels and an absence of plasma iduronate-2-sulfatase. Which of the following additional findings is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Optic atrophy is seen with Krabbe disease (galactocerebrosidase deficiency), in which there is an accumulation of galactocerebroside and psychosine. Like Hunter syndrome, it can manifest with cognitive impairment and peripheral neuropathy but does not involve iduronate-2-sulfatase deficiency.
Image Description:

Fundus photographs (a: left eye; b: right eye)

Optic nerve pallor, a characteristic manifestation of optic atrophy, is visible.

B) INCORRECT:

Pancytopenia can be seen in Gaucher disease, which is characterized by the accumulation of glucocerebroside and is also associated with hepatosplenomegaly. However, this patient lacks other typical features such as aseptic necrosis of the femur, bone crises, and Gaucher cells. Furthermore, Gaucher disease is due to glucocerebrosidase deficiency, rather than the iduronate-2-sulfatase deficiency observed in this patient. Patients with Gaucher disease can be managed with enzyme replacement therapy with recombinant glucocerebrosidase.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a bone marrow smear from a patient with bilateral femoral neck necrosis (PAS stain)

A large cell (yellow overlay) with an eccentric nucleus (green overlay) can be seen. The cytoplasm shows a striated pattern.

This is the typical appearance of a Gaucher cell, as seen in Gaucher disease.

C) INCORRECT:

A cherry-red spot on the macula can be seen in both Niemann-Pick disease (sphingomyelinase deficiency) and Tay-Sachs disease (hexosaminidase A deficiency). Patients with Niemann-Pick disease accumulate sphingomyelin, while those with Tay-Sachs disease accumulate GM2 ganglioside. While Niemann-Pick disease is associated with hepatosplenomegaly, which is seen in this patient, Tay-Sachs disease is not. Neither disorder is associated with the coarse facial features, enlarged tongue, or deficiency of iduronate-2-sulfatase seen in this patient.
Image Description:

Fundus photography of a young child

The fovea (in the center of the photograph) appears bright red because the well-perfused choroid shines through the thin retinal layer consisting of only photoreceptors here. In contrast, the surrounding retina, which consists of several layers, appears lighter with lipid storage or retinal ischemia blocking the aspect of the choroid.

A cherry-red spot of the retina can be seen in lipid storage diseases (in this case, Tay-Sachs disease) and in central artery occlusion of the retina.

D) INCORRECT:

Hurler syndrome (mucopolysaccharidosis type I) is an autosomal recessive lysosomal storage disease caused by a deficiency in α-L-iduronidase. Unlike Hunter syndrome (mucopolysaccharidosis type II), it is associated with more severe developmental delay, cognitive impairment, and corneal clouding. While it does manifest with coarse facial features, carpal tunnel syndrome, hepatosplenomegaly, and heparan sulfate and dermatan sulfate accumulation, it is not associated with the iduronate-2-sulfatase deficiency seen here.

Hurler syndrome can be effectively managed with enzyme replacement therapy with recombinant α-L-iduronidase and symptomatic treatment (orthopedic care, corneal transplantation).
Image Description:

There is white-gray clouding of the cornea, making details of the iris appear blurred.

Corneal clouding is seen in a variety of diseases (here: mucopolysaccharidosis VI).

E) CORRECT:

Hunter syndrome is an X-linked recessive lysosomal storage disease caused by a deficiency in iduronate-2-sulfatase and is associated with aggressive behavior, developmental delay, cognitive impairment, carpal tunnel syndrome, and hepatosplenomegaly. Unlike Hurler syndrome (mucopolysaccharidosis type I), it is not associated with corneal clouding.
questions.hint: Iduronate-2-sulfatase is the deficient enzyme in Hunter syndrome (mucopolysaccharidosis type II). Patients with Hunter syndrome accumulate heparan sulfate and dermatan sulfate.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician for evaluation of recurrent falls and clumsiness. He can only walk with support, and his vocabulary consists of approximately 20 words. He cannot hold objects or stack blocks. Physical examination shows coarse facial features and scoliosis. A holosystolic murmur is heard at the apex. The abdomen is distended, and both the liver and spleen tips are palpable. Fundoscopic examination shows cloudy corneas. Laboratory studies show complete inactivity of the N-acetylglucosaminyl-1-phosphotransferase enzyme. This condition is most likely associated with an accumulation of which of the following substances in the patient's serum?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Lysosomal phosphatase and other lysosomal enzymes accumulate in the serum of patients with I-cell disease. In this condition, the Golgi apparatus fails to phosphorylate mannose residues to mannose-6-phosphate on glycoproteins. Since phosphorylated mannose is a marker for exportation to the lysosome, I-cell disease results in inappropriate extracellular secretion of proteins intended for the lysosome.
Image Description:

The Golgi apparatus is composed of cisternae, which are arranged in a convex cis or a concave trans face. The cis face receives transport vesicles from transitional ER (1). These contain cargo proteins as well as other proteins of the ER, which are sent back to the transitional ER. Cargo proteins are further transported from one cistern to the other and are modified (e.g., glycosylated) during the process (2). At the trans face, vesicles detach and reach the cell membrane, where they fuse together. Through fusion, membrane proteins (3) or secretory proteins (4) are transported to their destination. Other vesicles contain acidic enzymes labeled with mannose-6-phosphate and are detached from the Golgi apparatus by the protein clathrin in order to form primary lysosomes (5).

B) INCORRECT:

Heparan sulfate, as well as dermatan sulfate, accumulate in the lysosomes of patients with Hurler syndrome and Hunter syndrome. This patient exhibits some signs of these conditions, which include developmental delay, coarse facies, and hepatosplenomegaly in both conditions, and corneal clouding in Hurler syndrome. However, these conditions are caused by deficiencies of enzymes responsible for lysosomal degradation of those glycosaminoglycans (iduronate-2-sulfatase in Hunter syndrome, α-L-iduronidase in Hurler syndrome), not by inactivity of N-acetylglucosaminyl-1-phosphotransferase.

C) INCORRECT:

Ceramide trihexoside accumulates in the vascular endothelium, organ epithelium, and in smooth muscle cells of patients with Fabry disease. This condition is caused by a deficiency of α-galactosidase A and typically manifests with a triad of episodic peripheral neuropathy, angiokeratomas, and hypohidrosis, which are not seen in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Sphingomyelin accumulates in the liver, spleen, bone marrow, and brain of patients with Niemann-Pick disease due to sphingomyelinase deficiency. Affected individuals often have delayed neurocognitive development and hepatosplenomegaly. Fundoscopic exam, however, classically shows a cherry red macula without corneal changes.

E) INCORRECT:

Glucocerebroside accumulates in the brain, liver, spleen, and bone marrow of patients with Gaucher disease due to glucocerebrosidase deficiency. Affected patients often develop hepatosplenomegaly. However, corneal clouding and neurocognitive delay are uncommon. Moreover, Gaucher disease typically causes pancytopenia and bony abnormalities (e.g., osteoporosis, avascular necrosis).
questions.hint: The presence of motor and language developmental abnormalities, in conjunction with coarse facial features, clouded corneas, scoliosis, and mitral regurgitation, are suggestive of a diagnosis of mucolipidosis type II (I-cell disease). N-acetylglucosaminyl-1-phosphotransferase normally phosphorylates mannose-6 residues.

questions.text: A 9-month-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents for multiple episodes of unresponsiveness in which she stares blankly and her eyelids flutter. She has gradually lost control of her neck and ability to roll over during the past 2 months. She is startled by loud noises and does not maintain eye contact. Her parents are of Ashkenazi Jewish descent. Neurological examination shows generalized hypotonia. Deep tendon reflexes are 3+ bilaterally. Fundoscopy shows bright red macular spots bilaterally. Abdominal examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following metabolites is most likely to accumulate due to this patient's disease?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cerebroside sulfate accumulates in metachromatic leukodystrophy, a condition that typically manifests with developmental delay, regression, and hypotonia starting at 6 months of age, which is similar to this patient's presentation. However, metachromatic leukodystrophy is not associated with bright red spots on the macula, but rather optic nerve atrophy, ataxia, and peripheral neuropathy.

B) INCORRECT:

Glucocerebroside accumulates in Gaucher disease (the most common of the sphingolipidoses). Gaucher disease typically manifests with hepatosplenomegaly, bone abnormalities (pain and osteopenia), and pancytopenia, and is more prevalent in individuals with Ashkenazi Jewish heritage. Affected individuals may also have seizures and developmental delay. However, bright red spots on the macula would not be seen.

C) INCORRECT:

Galactocerebroside and psychosine accumulate in Krabbe disease, a condition that typically manifests with developmental delay or regression, which is seen in this case. However, individuals with Krabbe disease tend to have hypertonia, not hypotonia, and Krabbe disease does not involve bright red spots on the macula. Instead, visual impairment occurs due to optic nerve atrophy and peripheral neuropathy.

D) INCORRECT:

Ceramide trihexoside accumulates in Fabry disease, a condition that typically manifests as severe distal limb pain (due to peripheral neuropathy) and angiokeratomas beginning around the age of 10–17 years. Renal failure and cardiovascular disease occur in most individuals between the ages of 30–40 years. However, the diagnosis of Fabry disease would not explain a developmental delay that started at 6 months of age, nor would it account for the bright red spots on the macula, hypotonia, or absence seizures in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Sphingomyelin accumulates in Niemann-Pick disease, a condition that typically manifests with neurodegeneration, bright red spots on the macula, developmental delay, and regression. Niemann-Pick disease is more common among individuals of Ashkenazi Jewish descent. However, it also usually causes hepatosplenomegaly, which this patient does not have.

F) CORRECT:

GM2 gangliosides accumulate in the neuronal cells of patients with Tay-Sachs disease. This accumulation is due to a deficiency of beta-hexosaminidase A. Affected patients typically present with progressive neurodegeneration, beginning around the age of 6 months, and cherry-red spots on fundoscopy. Individuals of Ashkenazi Jewish descent are more prone to developing the disease and carrier testing is therefore commonly performed in pregnant patients of this group or patients who wish to conceive. There is no cure and treatment is largely supportive. Usually, patients die of respiratory infections before 5 years of age.

Niemann-Pick disease may manifest without hepatosplenomegaly, which can make it very difficult to differentiate Niemann-Pick disease from Tay-Sachs disease without diagnostic histological evidence (i.e., of foam cells in Niemann-Pick disease and lysosomes with an onion skin appearance in Tay-Sachs disease). Nevertheless, when present, hepatosplenomegaly is usually the key differentiating clinical finding on exam questions.
questions.hint: This infant has Tay-Sachs disease, a condition that typically manifests with developmental delay, regression of achieved milestones (e.g., loss of ability to roll over), absence seizures (episodes of unresponsiveness with a blank stare), decreased eye contact, hypotonia, exaggerated startle response (as a result of hyperacusis), and bright red spots on fundoscopy. This condition is more common in individuals of Ashkenazi Jewish descent.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents because of fever and recurrent episodes of jerky movements of his extremities for the past 6 hours. Pregnancy and delivery were uncomplicated, and development was normal until the age of 1 year. The parents report that he has had gradual loss of speech, vision, and motor skills over the past year. During this time, he has been admitted to the hospital three times because of myoclonic seizures. Physical examination shows hypertonicity of the upper and lower extremities. Fundoscopic examination shows pallor of the optic disc bilaterally. An MRI of the brain shows brain atrophy and hyperintensity of the periventricular and subcortical areas. Two days after admission, the patient dies. Histopathologic examination of the brain shows aggregation of globoid cells and loss of glial cells. The patient’s condition was most likely caused by a deficiency of which of the following enzymes?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A deficiency of sphingomyelinase, which leads to an accumulation of sphingomyelin mainly in the brain, liver, spleen and bone marrow, is the primary defect in Niemann-Pick disease (NPD). This condition can manifest with seizures and progressive neurodegeneration with brain atrophy. However, NPD is typically associated with hypotonia (not hypertonia), a cherry-red spot on the macula on fundoscopic examination (rather than optic disc pallor), interstitial lung disease, and hepatosplenomegaly, none of which is seen here. Moreover, globoid cells on brain biopsy are not a feature of NPD.

B) INCORRECT:

A deficiency of arylsulfatase A, which leads to an accumulation of cerebroside sulfate mainly in the central and peripheral nervous system, is the primary defect in metachromatic leukodystrophy (ML). ML can manifest with developmental regression (e.g., loss of speech and motor skills), brain and optic atrophy (optic pallor and vision loss), seizures, and loss of glial cells on brain biopsy, all of which are seen in this patient. However, globoid cells on brain biopsy are not a feature of this condition. Moreover, ML typically also manifests with ataxia and hypotonia (not hypertonia), which are not seen here.

C) INCORRECT:

A deficiency of β-glucocerebrosidase, which leads to an accumulation of glucocerebroside in the brain, liver, spleen, and bone marrow, is the primary defect in Gaucher disease. Some patients with this condition present with neurological complications such as developmental regression (e.g., loss of speech and motor skills), loss of vision (from macular atrophy and uveitis), and seizures. However, Gaucher disease is not associated with brain or optic atrophy (optic disc pallor) or globoid cells on brain biopsy. Instead, typical manifestations of Gaucher disease include hepatosplenomegaly, petechiae, painful bone crises, and pathological fractures, none of which is seen here.

D) INCORRECT:

A deficiency of β-hexosaminidase A, which leads to an accumulation of GM2 ganglioside mainly in the brain and retina, is the primary defect in Tay-Sachs disease (TSD). This condition can manifest with developmental regression (e.g., loss of speech and motor skills), vision loss, and seizures. However, TSD is typically also associated with muscle weakness and hypotonia (not hypertonia), hyperreflexia, hearing impairment and a cherry-red spot on the macula on fundoscopic examination (not optic disc pallor), none of which is present here. Moreover, brain biopsy of a patient with TSD typically reveals lysosomes with an onion skin appearance, not globoid cells.

E) CORRECT:

A deficiency of β-galactocerebrosidase, which leads to intracellular accumulation of myelin breakdown products (galactocerebroside and psychosine) in the central and peripheral nervous system, is the primary defect in Krabbe disease. Characteristic pathologic findings resulting from the toxic effect of these breakdown products include globoid cells and progressive loss of myelin sheaths. Krabbe disease most commonly manifests in early infancy with developmental regression (e.g., loss of speech and motor skills), fever, limb spasticity, brain and optic atrophy (optic disc pallor and vision loss), and seizures, as seen in this patient. Further symptoms include peripheral neuropathy, axial hypotonia, absent reflexes, and microcephaly. Progressive decerebration usually leads to death before the age of two.

Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation has been shown to improve outcomes if performed before the onset of symptoms.
Image Description:

The chart illustrates the breakdown of select sphingolipids in the lysosomes, the corresponding enzymes that catalyze the reactions, and the diseases that an enzyme defect can cause.

GM1, GM2, GM3, GA1, and GA2 refer to various gangliosides, i.e., sphingolipids with different sugar residues.

F) INCORRECT:

A deficiency of α-galactosidase A is the primary defect in Fabry disease and leads to an accumulation of ceramide trihexoside (globotriaosylceramide) in the endothelium of vessels, the epithelium of many organs, and smooth muscle cells. This condition classically manifests during late childhood with paresthesias and neuropathic pain, hypohidrosis, angiokeratomas, asymptomatic cataracts, and gastrointestinal symptoms. This patient's presentation is not consistent with Fabry disease.
questions.hint: Giant, multinucleated histiocytes (globoid cells) on histopathologic examination of the brain are diagnostic of Krabbe disease.

questions.text:
A 31-year-old woman reports a 6-month history of increasing abdominal fullness and left-sided abdominal pain. She has not had any fevers or night sweats but reports early satiety and a 4.5-kg weight loss during the past year. Recently, she has also experienced frequent bruising without bleeding. She mentions that she has frequent pain in her hips and knees. Her only medicines are calcium and vitamin D supplements.
On examination, she is afebrile with normal vital signs; she appears tired. No lymphadenopathy is present. Cardiac and pulmonary examinations are normal. Her abdomen is soft but mildly distended, without focal tenderness. She has moderate hepatomegaly and a spleen that is palpable 10 cm below the left costal margin. On musculoskeletal examination, there is no spinal tenderness, but she does grimace on active range of motion exercises in the hips and knees. Her skin shows yellow-brown pigmentation. Her neurologic examination is normal.
Laboratory results are as follows:



Patient value
Reference range


Leukocyte count (per mm3)
3800
4500–11,000


Hemoglobin (g/dL)
8.5
12.0–16.0


Hematocrit (%)
26
36–46


Platelet count (per mm3)
45,000
150,000–350,000


Total bilirubin (mg/dL)
0.9
0.3–1.0


Direct bilirubin (mg/dl)
0.2
0.1–0.3


Aspartate aminotransferase (U/liter)
55
0–35


Alanine aminotransferase (U/liter)
75
0–35


Alkaline phosphatase (U/liter)
361
30–120


The differential count is normal; the peripheral-blood smear is normal other than the finding of pancytopenia. There is no myeloid immaturity or blasts. There are no teardrop-shaped or nucleated red cells. There is no obvious dysplasia on the smear.
A dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry scan, performed to further evaluate the pain in her hips and knees, reveals moderate osteoporosis (figure).
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Myelofibrosis is unlikely, given the absence of leukoerythroblastic findings (e.g., teardrop or nucleated red cells, or myeloid immaturity) on the blood smear.

B) CORRECT:

Gaucher disease, the most common lysosomal storage disease, is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by a deficiency of the glucocerebrosidase enzyme, causing the accumulation of glycolipids. Clinical manifestations of the disease include hepatosplenomegaly and bone disease. Bone disease may manifest as bone pain or swelling, aseptic necrosis, or osteoporosis. This patient’s imaging reveals flaring of the distal femur, the most typical finding; there is also evidence of marrow infarctions, and there are secondary osteoarthritic changes due to subchondral bony collapse resulting from osteonecrosis. Splenomegaly can lead to thrombocytopenia and anemia from splenic sequestration. Type 1 Gaucher disease, the most common type, rarely causes neurologic symptoms or signs and is more common among Ashkenazi Jews.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in a patient who has pancytopenia without myeloid immaturity or leukoerythroblastosis, massive hepatosplenomegaly without lymphadenopathy, and bone pain is Gaucher disease.

C) INCORRECT:

Amyloidosis is not associated with massive hepatosplenomegaly.

D) INCORRECT:

Hodgkin lymphoma is unlikely in the absence of lymphadenopathy and/or other B symptoms, given the findings of splenomegaly and pancytopenia.

E) INCORRECT:

Chronic myeloid leukemia would be unlikely, given a lack of myeloid immaturity and the absence of an elevated leukocyte count.

questions.text:
A 7-month-old boy is hospitalized for evaluation of abnormal movements, which consist of quick jerking movements of both upper extremities to the midline, triggered by loud noises, and unprovoked quick jerking movements of single extremities. He was able to tripod-sit at 4 months of age but is not yet sitting independently. His growth parameters are tracking along his growth curve.
During examination, he does not focus on the clinician or mimic facial expressions. There is no hepatosplenomegaly. He has truncal hypotonia, 3+ deep-tendon reflexes at the patella, and sustained ankle clonus bilaterally. Funduscopic examination is notable for the following results:
There is no electroencephalographic correlate for the movements.
Which one of the following interventions is most appropriate for this patient and his family?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Nutrient restriction is the treatment of choice for disorders of intermediary metabolism, many of which can manifest as subacute neurologic regression (e.g., phenylketonuria and glutaric aciduria type 1). In Tay-Sachs disease, the deficiency is in breaking down ganglioside monosialic 2, an endogenously synthesized sphingolipid, so dietary restriction is not beneficial.

B) INCORRECT:

Enzyme-replacement therapy is the standard treatment for non-central nervous system manifestations of lysosomal storage disorders. Most enzymes are too large to cross the blood-brain barrier and therefore have no effect on the neurologic manifestations of these disorders. There is no enzyme-replacement therapy available for Tay-Sachs disease.

C) INCORRECT:

Antiepileptic therapy is a mainstay of treatment in Tay-Sachs disease once seizures develop, usually around 12 months of age. However, early introduction of this treatment has no benefit, and the early abnormal movements associated with Tay-Sachs disease (myoclonic jerk and easy startle) do not respond to antiepileptic therapy.

D) CORRECT:

This patient has classic infantile Tay-Sachs disease (also called GM2 gangliosidosis), a lysosomal storage disease caused by a deficiency of hexosaminidase A due to mutations in the HEXA gene. This case could also be consistent with the infantile forms of other gangliosidoses: Sandhoff disease (hexosaminidase B deficiency) or GM1 gangliosidosis (beta-galactosidase deficiency). These ultra-rare disorders are similar clinically.

Infantile Tay-Sachs disease is characterized by progressive and ultimately fatal neurodegeneration. The first symptoms typically appear at about 6 months of age and include an easily provoked Moro reflex (classically prompted by loud noise), myoclonic jerks, decreased visual attentiveness, and developmental slowing and regression. Early findings on examination include hypotonia, hyperreflexia, ankle clonus, and perifoveal pallor with central clearing (often referred to as a cherry-red spot, although the redness reflects the normal fovea centralis, made prominent by surrounding lipid storage). By 6 to 10 months of age, affected patients experience rapid vision loss and decline of voluntary movement. Seizures develop by one year of age and eventually become refractory to treatment. By 2 years, affected children develop decerebrate posturing and are minimally responsive to their environment. The disease is inevitably fatal. The most common cause of death in patients with Tay-Sachs disease is pneumonia, usually aspiration pneumonia related to hypotonia and poor swallowing.

Although placement of an enteral feeding tube will prolong the life of a child with Tay-Sachs disease, it will not alter the inexorable neurodegenerative course of this disease. Discussing goals of care with the family is therefore critical. During this discussion, clinicians are advised to introduce the involvement of pediatric palliative care services to develop a comprehensive plan of care for the caregivers (addressing issues such as caregiver fatigue, mental health, respite care, grieving), for the siblings (coping, mental health, and grieving), and for the patient themselves (home nursing, advanced directives, do-not-resuscitate orders).

Notably, rigorous screening has led to a >90% decline in the incidence of Tay-Sachs disease among Ashkenazi Jews; as a result, most U.S. cases now occur in non-Ashkenazi families (French Canadian, Cajun, Irish, and other ethnic groups).

Key learning point: Increased startle response, myoclonic jerks, and perifoveal pallor are early hallmarks of Tay-Sachs disease.

E) INCORRECT:

Hematopoietic stem-cell transplantation (HSCT) has been attempted in children with Tay-Sachs disease but does not prevent neurologic deterioration. It is an effective treatment in some other lysosomal storage diseases with neurologic manifestations, such as mucopolysaccharidosis type I (MPS I). For the best outcomes in MPS I, HSCT must be initiated within the first 12 months of life. HSCT has also been used in Krabbe disease, which could be on the differential diagnosis for this patient because it features infantile regression and perifoveal pallor, although this patient does not have spasticity, which is usually seen in Krabbe disease. For HSCT to be beneficial in Krabbe disease, it must be performed before symptom onset.

questions.text:
A 2-year-old girl is brought in by her parents who are concerned about her overall health and would like to establish care. They were recently referred to otolaryngology for consideration of myringotomy tubes because of recurrent ear infections and speech delay. In addition, the girl has gross motor delay, snores at night, and required surgical correction of an inguinal hernia at one year of age.
She has normal vital signs with height at the 5th percentile, weight at the 15th percentile, and head circumference at the 95th percentile. On examination, she is noted to have thick, prominent eyebrows and lips, macroglossia, large tonsils, and hazy corneas. There is a systolic murmur over the apex, hepatosplenomegaly, and joint stiffness of the elbows and ankles.
A radiograph of the skull shows thickening of the calvarium.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome might be suspected in this case because of the macroglossia, but this syndrome is associated with overgrowth and the patient in this case is small for her age.

B) INCORRECT:

Although patients with beta-thalassemia can present with hepatosplenomegaly and an associated murmur related to anemia, the other features observed in this patient (e.g., corneal clouding, macrocephaly, and coarse facial features) are not typical in beta-thalassemia and should lead to consideration of other diagnoses in the differential.

C) INCORRECT:

Infantile Pompe disease is a lysosomal storage disorder associated with macroglossia; however, patients with this condition do not have coarse facial features, and they present with severe hypotonia and evidence of biventricular cardiac hypertrophy with or without signs of heart failure.

D) INCORRECT:

Tay-Sachs disease is a lysosomal storage disease associated with developmental regression, poor growth, hypotonia, and vision and hearing impairments. The classic ophthalmologic finding is a cherry red spot, not hazy corneas.

E) CORRECT:

This patient most likely has mucopolysaccharidosis type I (MPS I), an autosomal recessive lysosomal storage disorder that results from a deficiency of the alpha-L-iduronidase enzyme. Testing for activity of this enzyme is part of newborn screening in some U.S. states but not all.

Symptoms in MPS I result from the accumulation of glycosaminoglycans (GAGs) in various tissues and organs, leading to a multisystem disorder. Coarse facial features result from accumulation of GAGs in the oral-facial region and frontal bones. Skeletal deposition of GAGs leads to an accumulation of storage material in the bones, known as dysostosis multiplex. Accumulation of GAGs in the brain causes intellectual disability. Presence of seizures is variable in MPS I.

Other organs also show GAG storage, most notably the eustachian tubes, tongue, tonsils, liver, spleen, heart, and cornea. GAG storage in eustachian tubes often results in frequent ear infections and hearing loss. Macroglossia and tonsillitis can cause airway obstruction. Hepatosplenomegaly in this disease is not typically associated with organ dysfunction. GAG storage in the heart may occur and cause cardiomyopathy, arrhythmia, and coronary artery disease. Corneal clouding is observed in MPS I and should be monitored regularly in these patients. Patients with MPS I also commonly suffer from diarrhea and constipation, although the cause of this is not fully understood.

The severity of symptoms in MPS I varies from the mildest form with intact cognition to the most severe form with significant cognitive impairment. Symptoms in MPS I and MPS II (Hunter syndrome) are very similar. However, MPS II is an X-linked disorder and does not manifest with corneal clouding.

Key learning point: Developmental delay, coarse facial features, macroglossia, hepatosplenomegaly, skeletal dysplasia, and corneal clouding are symptoms of mucopolysaccharidosis type I.

questions.text:
A 6-month-old infant presents with poor feeding, frequent bruising, and progressive abdominal distension over the past few weeks. Examination shows pallor and severe hepatosplenomegaly. Laboratory tests reveal normocytic anemia and thrombocytopenia with a normal leukocyte count (see report).
Bone marrow aspiration: Numerous lipid-laden macrophages with a distinctive 'wrinkled tissue paper' appearance of the cytoplasm, without malignant blast forms
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Juvenile myelomonocytic leukemia (JMML) presents with hepatosplenomegaly, anemia, and thrombocytopenia, but typically shows leukocytosis with monocytosis and dysplastic myeloid cells. The 'wrinkled tissue paper' macrophages in the bone marrow are not characteristic of JMML.

B) INCORRECT:

Niemann-Pick disease, caused by sphingomyelinase deficiency, leads to sphingomyelin accumulation. It presents with hepatosplenomegaly and cytopenias, but bone marrow aspirates show foam cells with vacuolated cytoplasm, not the 'wrinkled tissue paper' appearance seen in Gaucher disease.

C) CORRECT:

Gaucher disease is a lysosomal storage disorder caused by a deficiency of the enzyme glucocerebrosidase, leading to the accumulation of glucocerebroside in macrophages. These macrophages exhibit a 'wrinkled tissue paper' appearance on cytological examination. The accumulation of these lipid-laden macrophages in the bone marrow results in normocytic anemia and thrombocytopenia, while their infiltration into the liver and spleen causes marked hepatosplenomegaly. Diagnosis is confirmed through biochemical assays measuring enzyme activity.

Key learning point: In infants presenting with massive hepatosplenomegaly and systemic symptoms, bone marrow aspiration is a key diagnostic tool to evaluate for hematological disorders such as leukemia or storage diseases.

D) INCORRECT:

Langerhans cell histiocytosis involves clonal proliferation of Langerhans cells, presenting with lytic bone lesions and skin manifestations. It is characterized by reniform nuclei and Birbeck granules, not lipid-laden macrophages with 'wrinkled tissue paper' cytoplasm.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his mother because of a 6-month history of burning pain in his hands and feet that worsens after exercise and during hot weather. He has also noticed red-purple spots on his lower abdomen and upper thighs. He has experienced episodes of abdominal pain and diarrhea for the past year and often misses school due to fatigue. His past medical history is significant for frequent ear infections during childhood. Family history shows that his maternal uncle died at age 38 of kidney failure. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 128/78 mm Hg. Physical examination shows decreased pinprick and temperature sensation in the distal extremities and multiple nonblanching, clustered, red-purple papules on the lower abdomen and groin. Serum creatinine concentration is 1.6 mg/dL. Urinalysis shows proteinuria. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hereditary motor sensory neuropathy (HMSN) often manifests with progressive sensory loss and neuropathic pain, usually starting in adolescence or adulthood. However, this patient presents with angiokeratomas, gastrointestinal symptoms, and early-onset renal failure, which are not typical manifestations of HMSN.

B) INCORRECT:

IgA vasculitis (IgAV) most commonly manifests in children with palpable purpura on the lower extremities, abdominal pain, and renal involvement. IgAV is often preceded by an upper respiratory tract or gastrointestinal infection, and does not typically manifest with neuropathic pain or a positive family history.
Image Description:

Photograph of the leg of an 18-year-old male patient

Multiple well-defined erythematous skin lesions (purpura) are visible. Some purpura have coalesced to form ecchymoses. Examination revealed the purpura to be palpable and nonblanchable.

The tetrad of purpura, arthritis, abdominal pain, and kidney impairment is typical of IgA vasculitis. Histopathology is required to confirm the diagnosis of IgA vasculitis.

C) CORRECT:

Fabry disease typically manifests during childhood with severe neuropathic pain triggered by exercise or heat, angiokeratomas (nonblanching red-purple papules) usually on the lower trunk and groin, and hypohydrosis. Gastrointestinal symptoms (e.g., abdominal pain, diarrhea) and early progressive renal disease (e.g., proteinuria, elevated creatinine) are common. Fabry disease is an X-linked recessive inheritance disease, and a family history of early-onset renal failure in a male relative supports the diagnosis. Long-term complications include progressive renal, cardiac, and cerebrovascular disease. Treatment of this condition involves enzyme replacement therapy with α-galactosidase A.
Image Description:

Multiple red/purple lesions are visible along the left groin of this adult male. Upon examination, these spots are palpably elevated.

This appearance is characteristic of angiokeratoma, which is caused by dilated dermal capillaries and hyperkeratosis of the overlying skin. Multiple diffusely-occurring angiokeratomas are a feature of Fabry disease.

D) INCORRECT:

Alport syndrome often manifests with progressive renal failure and is more common in patients with a family history of kidney failure. However, this patient presents with neuropathic pain, angiokeratomas, and gastrointestinal symptoms, which do not manifest in Alport syndrome. In addition, patients with Alport syndrome typically present with hematuria, sensorineural hearing loss, and ocular abnormalities.

E) INCORRECT:

Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) can manifest with fatigue, renal involvement, and nonspecific gastrointestinal symptoms. However, SLE is rare in prepubertal boys and typically manifests with additional findings (e.g., malar rash, arthritis, serositis, cytopenias). In addition, SLE does not manifest with neuropathic pain or angiokeratomas.

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents because of a 6-month history of progressive difficulty walking and speaking. Her parents also report that she has recently started having trouble feeding herself and appears to be losing interest in playing. She was born at full term following an uncomplicated pregnancy and delivery, and her early development was within normal limits. Family history is notable for a paternal aunt who had a progressive neurological disorder and died in her early 20s. On examination, the girl is listless and has difficulty following commands. She has poor head control and generalized hypotonia. Deep tendon reflexes are diminished in all four extremities. Funduscopic examination reveals bilateral optic atrophy. Nerve conduction studies show symmetrically decreased conduction velocities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Tay-Sachs disease (TSD) is caused by hexosaminidase A deficiency, leading to GM2 ganglioside accumulation and progressive neurodegeneration. Symptoms typically appear at 3–6 months of age and include developmental delay, hypotonia, and characteristic ophthalmological findings. In TSD, however, the hallmark ocular feature is a cherry-red spot on the macula, not optic nerve atrophy, and patients have hyperreflexia rather than hyporeflexia. Peripheral neuropathy and decreased nerve conduction velocity are not features of TSD. Additionally, this patient does not have other expected manifestations of TSD, such as hyperacusis and seizures.

B) CORRECT:

Metachromatic leukodystrophy is an autosomal recessive lysosomal storage disorder caused by arylsulfatase A (ARSA) deficiency, resulting in the accumulation of sulfatides that are toxic to oligodendrocytes and Schwann cells. This leads to progressive demyelination in both the central and peripheral nervous systems. Childhood onset is characterized by psychomotor regression, impaired memory, hypotonia, hyporeflexia, ataxia, and optic nerve atrophy that can lead to vision loss. Nerve conduction studies reveal decreased velocities due to demyelination. Metachromatic leukodystrophy is diagnosed by finding deficient ARSA enzyme activity in peripheral blood leukocytes or dried blood spots, and/or by identifying pathogenic mutations in the ARSA gene. A positive family history of progressive neurological decline supports the diagnosis of genetic leukodystrophy.

C) INCORRECT:

Krabbe disease is caused by galactocerebrosidase deficiency, which leads to progressive demyelination. In childhood, this condition typically manifests with significant mental and motor deficits, including developmental delay, peripheral neuropathy, and optic nerve atrophy that can lead to vision loss. However, Krabbe disease commonly manifests within the first year of life, and affected infants initially have limb stiffness rather than hypotonia.

D) INCORRECT:

Rett syndrome is an X-linked dominant genetic disorder caused by a mutation in the MECP2 gene. This condition almost exclusively affects girls and manifests with neurodevelopmental regression, including loss of motor skills, intellectual and verbal disability, and ataxia. Peripheral neuropathy, decreased nerve conduction velocity, hypotonia, and optic atrophy are not features of Rett syndrome. Additionally, this patient does not present with typical symptoms of the condition, such as scoliosis, hyperventilation, microcephaly, and characteristic hand wringing.

E) INCORRECT:

Niemann-Pick disease (NPD) is a lysosomal storage disorder caused by sphingomyelinase deficiency that leads to sphingomyelin accumulation and progressive neurodegeneration. NPD typically manifests with psychomotor regression, hypotonia, hyporeflexia, and characteristic ophthalmological findings. However, the hallmark ocular finding in NPD is a cherry-red spot on the macula, not optic nerve atrophy. Peripheral neuropathy and decreased nerve conduction velocity are not features of NPD. In addition, this patient does not have common systemic findings of NPD, such as hepatosplenomegaly.
questions.hint: Deficient enzyme activity in leukocytes helps establish the diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 9-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother for evaluation of diffuse bone pain in his right leg. His family immigrated to the United States 6 months ago from northern Canada. He is below the 5th percentile for height and at the 10th percentile for weight. Physical examination shows tenderness to palpation of the right distal femur. There is hepatosplenomegaly. An x-ray of right femur shows generalized trabecular thinning and several osteolytic bone lesions. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
9.2 g/dL


Leukocyte count
7,600/mm3


Platelets
71,000/mm3


A bone marrow aspirate shows mononuclear cells filled with lipid that appear like wrinkled silk. Deficiency of which of the following enzymes is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A deficiency of sphingomyelinase is the cause of Niemann-Pick disease, an autosomal recessive lysosomal storage disease. While developmental delay and hepatosplenomegaly are features of Niemann-Pick disease, osteolytic bone lesions and anemia would not be expected. Also, “cherry-red” spots on the macula is a feature of the condition that is not seen in this patient. Although bone marrow aspirate of a patient with Niemann-Pick disease would show lipid-laden macrophages, they would not resemble wrinkled silk.

B) INCORRECT:

A deficiency of α-galactosidase A is the cause of Fabry disease, the only x-linked recessive lysosomal storage disease. Osteolytic bone lesions, hepatosplenomegaly, anemia, thrombocytopenia, developmental delay, and lipid-filled macrophages would not be expected in this disease. Early clinical manifestations of the condition include peripheral neuropathy, angiokeratomas, and corneal opacities. Late clinical signs include cardiomyopathy, cerebrovascular events, and Fabry nephropathy. This patient has none of these clinical features.

C) INCORRECT:

A deficiency of Arylsulfatase A is the cause of metachromatic leukodystrophy, an autosomal recessive lysosomal storage disease. Although developmental delay is a feature of this condition, osteolytic bone lesions, hepatosplenomegaly, anemia, thrombocytopenia, and lipid-filled macrophages would not be expected. Also, ataxia, dementia, and peripheral neuropathy are features of childhood- and juvenile-onset metachromatic leukodystrophy that are not seen in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

A deficiency of galactocerebrosidase is the cause of Krabbe disease, an autosomal recessive lysosomal storage disease. Although developmental delay is a feature of the condition, osteolytic bone lesions, hepatosplenomegaly, anemia, thrombocytopenia, and lipid-filled macrophages would not be expected. Also, peripheral neuropathy, limb stiffness, opisthotonic posture, and loss of vision are features of Krabbe disease that are not seen in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

A deficiency of hexosaminidase A is the cause of Tay-Sachs disease, an autosomal recessive lysosomal storage disease. Although developmental delay is a feature of this disease, osteolytic bone lesions, hepatosplenomegaly, anemia, thrombocytopenia, and lipid-filled macrophages would not be expected. Also, “cherry-red” spots on the macula, hypotonia, seizures, and hearing impairment are features of the condition that are not seen in this patient.

F) CORRECT:

A deficiency of β-glucocerebrosidase is the cause of Gaucher disease, an autosomal recessive lysosomal storage disease. Type I, non-neuronopathic Gaucher disease manifests with hepatosplenomegaly, bone pathology, anemia, thrombocytopenia, and growth delays. Diagnosis of a patient with suggestive clinical features is confirmed by the finding of reduced glucocerebrosidase activity, often in peripheral leukocytes or fibroblasts. Treatment is with recombinant glucocerebrosidase. Type II, acute neuronopathic Gaucher disease manifests with hepatosplenomegaly, congenital ichthyosis, and rapidly progressive neurodegeneration; affected patients usually die before 2 years of age.

See “Overview of lysosomal storage diseases” table.
Image Description:

The chart illustrates the breakdown of select sphingolipids in the lysosomes, the corresponding enzymes that catalyze the reactions, and the diseases that an enzyme defect can cause.

GM1, GM2, GM3, GA1, and GA2 refer to various gangliosides, i.e., sphingolipids with different sugar residues.
questions.hint: This patient presents with osteolytic bone lesions, hepatosplenomegaly, developmental delay, anemia, thrombocytopenia, and lipid-filled macrophages that resemble crumbled silk. These clinical findings are characteristic of a disease that, in one of its more severe variants, can feature congenital ichthyosis (“collodion baby”).
